note.plain:
Chance.  This is yet another example of the many forced comparisons in .  The Ngaju Dayak form clearly reflects PMP *leŋen ‘forearm, lower arm’.  The loss of 
word-final -n in obligatorily possessed nouns has led to reanalysis in other languages of Borneo, as in Uma Juman Kayan, where the reflex of PMP *ipen ‘tooth’ in constructions such as ipen-naɁ ‘his/her tooth’ has be reinterpreted as ipeɁ-naɁ ‘his/her tooth’ (with obligatory morpheme-final glottal stop).  The Fijian word is most likely a reflex of POc *lima ‘hand’, with a sporadic replacement of *m by its labiovelar equivalent, as with Mota limwa ‘hand; five’.  Dempwolff ignored the irregularity in the vowel correspondences of both syllables, and proposed Uraustronesisch *liŋa ‘hand, arm’ despite the availability of far better-supported words for this meaning.
note.markdown:
Chance.  This is yet another example of the many forced comparisons in [Dempwolff (1938)](bib-Dempwolff).  The __language__Ngaju Dayak__ form clearly reflects __language__PMP__ *_leŋen_ ‘forearm, lower arm’.  The loss of 
word-final _-n_ in obligatorily possessed nouns has led to reanalysis in other languages of Borneo, as in __language__Uma Juman Kayan__, where the reflex of __language__PMP__ *_ipen_ ‘tooth’ in constructions such as _ipen-naɁ_ ‘his/her tooth’ has be reinterpreted as _ipeɁ-naɁ_ ‘his/her tooth’ (with obligatory morpheme-final glottal stop).  The __language__Fijian__ word is most likely a reflex of __language__POc__ *_lima_ ‘hand’, with a sporadic replacement of *_m_ by its labiovelar equivalent, as with __language__Mota__ _limwa_ ‘hand; five’.  Dempwolff ignored the irregularity in the vowel correspondences of both syllables, and proposed Uraustronesisch *_liŋa_ ‘hand, arm’ despite the availability of far better-supported words for this meaning.

note.plain: Tempting as it is to accept this as a valid comparison, the sound correspondences simply do not work.  The Puyuma vowels disagree with those of the Paiwan and Ibaloy forms, and although the latter two languages appear to show a perfect agreement, Paiwan /s/ reflects *S and Ibaloy /s/ reflects *s, making reconstruction impossible.  Like many other bases with initial velar nasal, this one probably is a product of convergent innovation involving the phonestheme ŋ-, widely associated in Austronesian languages with the nasal-oral area.
note.markdown: Tempting as it is to accept this as a valid comparison, the sound correspondences simply do not work.  The __language__Puyuma__ vowels disagree with those of the __language__Paiwan__ and __language__Ibaloy__ forms, and although the latter two languages appear to show a perfect agreement, __language__Paiwan__ /_s_/ reflects *_S_ and __language__Ibaloy__ /_s_/ reflects *_s_, making reconstruction impossible.  Like many other bases with initial velar nasal, this one probably is a product of convergent innovation involving the phonestheme _ŋ-_, widely associated in Austronesian languages with the nasal-oral area ([Blust 2003a](bib-Blust)).

posited *ketug ‘to beat, pound’ based on a comparison of this Tagalog form with Javanese ketug ‘to beat out’.  I am unable to find the latter form in either  or , and have substituted Old Javanese kətug for it.
In either case, until further supporting evidence is found this comparison is best treated as a product of chance.
note.markdown:
[Dempwolff (1938)](bib-Dempwolff) posited *_ketug_ ‘to beat, pound’ based on a comparison of this __language__Tagalog__ form with __language__Javanese__ _ketug_ ‘to beat out’.  I am unable to find the latter form in either [Horne (1974)](bib-Horne) or [Pigeaud (1938)](bib-Pigeaud), and have substituted __language__Old Javanese__ _kətug_ for it.
In either case, until further supporting evidence is found this comparison is best treated as a product of chance.

note.plain: This is an example of a type of comparison that is unfortunately rather common in , namely one in which the semantics of forms that would allow a higher-level reconstruction are extremely forced and artificial (the Ngaju Dayak and Javanese forms, which are semantically compatible, cannot safely support a reconstruction, given the longstanding Javanese influence on Banjarese and Ngaju Dayak).  Unlike most of the chance resemblances for which Dempwolff proposed PAn reconstructions this one also shows an unacknowledged phonological irregularity, since he cites Fijian i-tabi ‘flat basket’, while  instead gives tabe ‘to hold or carry with the hands under’, i-tabe ‘a small oval basket without handles’.

note.plain: This is one of the most remarkably speculative of all Dempwolff etymologies.  The forms in western Indonesia refer exclusively to spears or lances, and those in Polynesian languages to land crabs, but here he has tried to force a connection by assuming that the primary reference in the latter case is to the claw of the crab, imagined as somehow believed to be lance-like (rather than pincer-like, which is far more likely).   reconstructed ‘Uraustronesisch’ *tumbak ‘crab claw, lance’ (Krebsschere, Lanze).

note.plain: Although initially tempting, this comparison is problematic in two respects: 1. the final correspondence appears to be without parallel, 2. the referent in Philippine languages evidently is the bony structure of the body in general rather than the skull in particular. With regard to the first of these points  has argued for the reconstruction of PAn *-q, *-ʔ, and *-h. Amis foŋoh points to an etymon with *-h, but this is cohtradicted by all Philippine witnesses, which can indicate only *-q or *-ʔ.
note.markdown: Although initially tempting, this comparison is problematic in two respects: 1. the final correspondence appears to be without parallel, 2. the referent in __language__Philippine__ languages evidently is the bony structure of the body in general rather than the skull in particular. With regard to the first of these points [Zorc (1982:115)](bib-Zorc) has argued for the reconstruction of __language__PAn__ *_-q_, *_-ʔ_, and *_-h_. __language__Amis__ _foŋoh_ points to an etymon with *_-h_, but this is cohtradicted by all __language__Philippine__ witnesses, which can indicate only *_-q_ or *_-ʔ_.

note.plain: Based on a comparison of the above Tagalog, Malay, and Javanese words, together with Toba Batak tabu ‘alarm drum’,  reconstructed PAn *tabuq ‘drumstick’.  He then extended this inference to *tabuqan ‘yellowjacket wasp’ by suggesting that the latter is *tabuq-an, and is semantically linked with *tabuq through the drumming sound that the yellowjacket wasp reportedly makes.  However, I find nothing like the Toba Batak word he cites in , or in dictionaries of any other Batak language, and the Tagalog word is semantically very distant from the forms in western Indonesia.  In short, I consider this whole enterprise fanciful, since there is no sound evidence for *tabuq ‘drumstick’, and without this as a beginning the analysis of *tabuqan --- which is highly questionable on morphological and semantic grounds in any case --- is vacuous.
note.markdown: Based on a comparison of the above __language__Tagalog__, __language__Malay__, and __language__Javanese__ words, together with __language__Toba Batak__ _tabu_ ‘alarm drum’, [Dempwolff (1938)](bib-Dempwolff) reconstructed __language__PAn__ *_tabuq_ ‘drumstick’.  He then extended this inference to *_tabuqan_ ‘yellowjacket wasp’ by suggesting that the latter is *_tabuq-an_, and is semantically linked with *_tabuq_ through the drumming sound that the yellowjacket wasp reportedly makes.  However, I find nothing like the __language__Toba Batak__ word he cites in [Warneck (1906)](bib-Warneck), or in dictionaries of any other Batak language, and the __language__Tagalog__ word is semantically very distant from the forms in western Indonesia.  In short, I consider this whole enterprise fanciful, since there is no sound evidence for *_tabuq_ ‘drumstick’, and without this as a beginning the analysis of *_tabuqan_ --- which is highly questionable on morphological and semantic grounds in any case --- is vacuous.

note.plain: compares the Iban form with Malay keris bahari ‘kris with a long, narrow, straight blade’.  Other terms that may be related are Thao balis ‘iron (metal)’, and Kavalan baris ‘nail’.  However, the Thao word is clearly a loan, probably from Bunun (although our lexicographic resources for the latter are insufficient to determine this with certainty), and the semantically deviant Kavalan form evidently reflects a prototype with medial *l rather than *r or *R.  By way of counterbalancing these problems, there is a second comparison (Palawan Batak karát ‘rusty’, Malay karat ‘rust’) which provides independent support for an early knowledge of iron.  On balance, this is perhaps best regarded as a chance resemblance, but the number of suggestive forms and the potential value of a comparison with this meaning keeps hope alive.  The term *bari is discussed at some length in  and , where it is suggested that it may have referred to meteoric iron.
note.markdown: [Richards (1981:28)](bib-Richards) compares the __language__Iban__ form with __language__Malay__ _keris bahari_ ‘kris with a long, narrow, straight blade’.  Other terms that may be related are __language__Thao__ _balis_ ‘iron (metal)’, and __language__Kavalan__ _baris_ ‘nail’.  However, the __language__Thao__ word is clearly a loan, probably from __language__Bunun__ (although our lexicographic resources for the latter are insufficient to determine this with certainty), and the semantically deviant __language__Kavalan__ form evidently reflects a prototype with medial *_l_ rather than *_r_ or *_R_ ([Li and Tsuchida 2006:8](bib-Li)).  By way of counterbalancing these problems, there is a second comparison (__language__Palawan Batak__ _karát_ ‘rusty’, __language__Malay__ _karat_ ‘rust’) which provides independent support for an early knowledge of iron.  On balance, this is perhaps best regarded as a chance resemblance, but the number of suggestive forms and the potential value of a comparison with this meaning keeps hope alive.  The term *_bari_ is discussed at some length in [Blust (1976)](bib-Blust) and [Blust (1999)](bib-Blust), where it is suggested that it may have referred to meteoric iron.

note.plain: included these forms under ‘Uraustronesisch’ *zuluk ‘pierce, penetrate’ (Stechen).  However, there is little to recommend this comparison, which appears to be a collection of formally compatible words that have almost nothing else in common.  It is true that the meaning ‘penetrate, bore through’ in Toba Batak man-julluk is fairly similar to ‘put in, insert, sheathe’ in Samoan sulu, but the medial geminate is unexplained (Dempwolff wrote ju<l>luk), and it is further noteworthy that Tongan hulu ‘to fix one’s loincloth by tucking in one end of it at the waist; to tidy up the edges of a mat by tucking in the protruding ends’, was omitted despite its obvious cognation, presumably because it would weaken the argument for comparing the Samoan form with those in insular Southeast Asia
note.markdown: [Dempwolff (1938)](bib-Dempwolff) included these forms under ‘Uraustronesisch’ *_zuluk_ ‘pierce, penetrate’ (_Stechen_).  However, there is little to recommend this comparison, which appears to be a collection of formally compatible words that have almost nothing else in common.  It is true that the meaning ‘penetrate, bore through’ in __language__Toba Batak__ _man-julluk_ is fairly similar to ‘put in, insert, sheathe’ in __language__Samoan__ _sulu_, but the medial geminate is unexplained (Dempwolff wrote _ju<l>luk_), and it is further noteworthy that __language__Tongan__ _hulu_ ‘to fix one’s loincloth by tucking in one end of it at the waist; to tidy up the edges of a mat by tucking in the protruding ends’, was omitted despite its obvious cognation, presumably because it would weaken the argument for comparing the __language__Samoan__ form with those in insular Southeast Asia

note.plain: This comparison was the subject of a tortuous discussion in the earlier literature based on: 1. an approach to linguistic reconstruction which circumvented the normal scientific procedure of triangulation in the justification of inferences, and 2. a failure to distinguish directly inherited from borrowed forms (, ). The Ngaju Dayak, Iban and Malay words clearly reflect PAn *buRaw 'drive off, chase away, expel' with the atypical, but recurrent change *-aw > u. All other forms in island Southeast Asia appear to be Malay loans, as attested by lexical doubletting in Karo Batak, Toba Batak and Dairi-Pakpak Batak, where a directly inherited reflex of *buRaw is found next to the Malay loanword, with semantic differences that are consistent with a borrowing hypothesis. Given the relatively complete integration of this loanword into the affixational systems of some of these languages (e.g. Toba Batak, and the appearance of buru in Old Javanese texts it appears likely that this word was borrowed fairly early in most languages (perhaps during the classic Sriwijaya period, circa 7th century AD). The similarity of the Southeast Solomonic  forms to those in western Indonesia is attributed to chance.
note.markdown: This comparison was the subject of a tortuous discussion in the earlier literature based on: 1. an approach to linguistic reconstruction which circumvented the normal scientific procedure of triangulation in the justification of inferences, and 2. a failure to distinguish directly inherited from borrowed forms ([Dyen 1953:363ff](bib-Dyen), [Hendon 1964:377ff](bib-Hendon)). The __language__Ngaju Dayak__, __language__Iban__ and __language__Malay__ words clearly reflect __language__PAn__ *_buRaw_ 'drive off, chase away, expel' with the atypical, but recurrent change *_-aw_ > _u_. All other forms in island Southeast Asia appear to be __language__Malay__ loans, as attested by lexical doubletting in __language__Karo Batak__, __language__Toba Batak__ and __language__Dairi-Pakpak Batak__, where a directly inherited reflex of *_buRaw_ is found next to the __language__Malay__ loanword, with semantic differences that are consistent with a borrowing hypothesis. Given the relatively complete integration of this loanword into the affixational systems of some of these languages (e.g. __language__Toba Batak__, and the appearance of _buru_ in __language__Old Javanese__ texts it appears likely that this word was borrowed fairly early in most languages (perhaps during the classic Sriwijaya period, circa 7th century AD). The similarity of the __language__Southeast Solomonic__  forms to those in western Indonesia is attributed to chance.

note.plain: Convergent innovation. Most of the forms cited here show multiple iconicity, beginning with a low vowel which approximates the position of the mouth at the onset of a sneeze, proceeding through an alveolar or palatal fricative or affricate, which mimics the oral closure preceding the release of a sneeze, and ending with a high vowel (plus nasal), which mimics the narrowed oral aperture and partial nasal channel which typically terminates a sneeze.

This comparison is an intriguing example of how a spurious etymology can be manufactured and perpetuated by competent comparative linguists despite a telling lack of credentials.  glossed the Tagalog form 'tortured' and the Tongan form 'torture'. Although he rejected the phonologically irregular Samoan form,  otherwise accepted Dempwolff's comparison unchanged, including his glosses for Tagalog inís and Tongan ino. Neither Dempwolff's own sources ( for Tagalog,  for Tongan) nor reliable alternatives of more recent date ( for Tagalog,  for Tongan), however, support the discrepant glosses cited in .
note.markdown: Chance. This comparison is an intriguing example of how a spurious etymology can be manufactured and perpetuated by competent comparative linguists despite a telling lack of credentials. [Dempwolff (1938)](bib-Dempwolff) glossed the __language__Tagalog__ form 'tortured' and the __language__Tongan__ form 'torture'. Although he rejected the phonologically irregular __language__Samoan__ form, [Dyen (1953)](bib-Dyen) otherwise accepted Dempwolff's comparison unchanged, including his glosses for __language__Tagalog__ _inís_ and __language__Tongan__ _ino_. Neither Dempwolff's own sources ([Laktaw 1914](bib-Laktaw) for Tagalog, [Colomb 1890](bib-Colomb) for __language__Tongan__) nor reliable alternatives of more recent date ([Panganiban 1973](bib-Panganiban) for __language__Tagalog__, [Churchward 1959](bib-Churchward) for __language__Tongan__), however, support the discrepant glosses cited in [Dempwolff (1934-38)](bib-Dempwolff).

note.plain: It is tempting to consider Hanunóo buybúy a loan from one of the languages of northern Mindoro, and so recognize a PPh *buRbuR 'silk cotton tree: Ceiba pentandra'. However, this hypothesis fails to account for the appearance of a palatal glide in the Tagalog and Aklanon words without an implausible extension of the hypothesis to include these languages. The comparison thus appears to be a product of chance.
note.markdown: It is tempting to consider __language__Hanunóo__ _buybúy_ a loan from one of the languages of northern Mindoro, and so recognize a __language__PPh__ *_buRbuR_ 'silk cotton tree: _Ceiba pentandra_'. However, this hypothesis fails to account for the appearance of a palatal glide in the __language__Tagalog__ and __language__Aklanon__ words without an implausible extension of the hypothesis to include these languages. The comparison thus appears to be a product of chance.

note.plain: compared the Tagalog, Malay and Javanese forms and posited Uraustronesisch *lataq ‘weakness, debility, faintness’ (Schwäche).  However, to include Tagalog latáɁ in this comparison seems little short of absurd.  So far as we can determine from the evidence, then, this remarkable neurological/mental disorder, for which Java is famous among anthropologists, is a purely local development that may have originated in Java, where the extreme emphasis on courtesy and restraint may well trigger reactions in some individuals who carry an unconscious resentment of the social strictures under which they must live their lives.

However, to include __language__Tagalog__ _latáɁ_ in this comparison seems little short of absurd. note.plain: The middle morpheme of Paiwan si-tiav-an shows a perfect formal and semantic match with Kavalan siRab, but the base form is Paiwan tiaw ‘day before or after today’, with regular morphophonemic alternation between -w (< *w) and v, which normally reflects only *b.  Given this observation this comparison must be treated as a product of chance, despite its obvious appeal.  Why it is so similar to PAn *siRa ‘yesterday’ is unclear.
